entry.title: Sorting material by description during enter count for physical inventory document
entry.content:
Hi

We have a requirement to sort the material by the description while entering the count for a physical inventory document via MI04-Enter Count or via the FIORI tile "Manage Physical Inventory Count result". Currently neither of the options has that functionality to sort material by description. 

Regards

Manas

entry.title: cXML punchout catalog integrations with S/4 Hana
entry.content:
We are currently implementing punchout catalogs in our SAP S/4HANA instance. I did the configurations of these catalogs. But some of the catalogs cannot be connected. Those are cXML-based catalogs. OCI catalogs are working as expected. (We don"t have any SRM implemented.)

  1. Could you let me know why the cXML catalogs are not connected?
  2. is the any other configuration available to do the cXML catalog integrations?

entry.title: IK18 - mass deactivate multiple measurement documents
entry.content:
We are currently using transaction IK18 in SAP S/4HANA DIGITS, and we have a business need to mass deactivate multiple measurement documents at once. However, in the standard functionality, it is only possible to deactivate documents one by one ‚Äî there is no option to select multiple entries and perform a mass deactivation.

I have already searched for a business function, user exit, BAdI, or enhancement that could allow this functionality, but I was not successful in finding anything available.

Could you please let me know:

  1. Is there any standard functionality, business function, or configuration that enables mass deactivation of measurement documents in IK18?

  2. If not, is there any recommended approach for implementing a custom development (e.g., BAdI, enhancement, or custom transaction/report) to achieve this?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Selective Data Transition: Functional Advantages of Selective Migration
entry.content:
Beyond Migration: Unlocking Business Transformation with Selective Data Transition

Many companies today face the challenge of transitioning their complex ERP landscapes to SAP S/4HANA. The pressure is on to not only modernize technically but also to position themselves functionally for the future. While traditional approaches often emphasize a purely technical migration, Selective Data Transition (SDT) offers a broader perspective: it enables companies to embed functional, organizational, and process improvements directly into the transformation without sacrificing valuable data or historical insights.

 

Shaping Transformation Instead of Just Migrating

At its core, Selective Data Transition is not simply about selective data migration. The migration approach becomes a strategic lever to actively shape the future ERP system. Companies are no longer bound to a one-to-one copy of their legacy systems. Instead, they can modernize processes, consolidate system landscapes, and integrate new functionalities ‚Äì all with purpose and direction.

This is particularly valuable for organizations with highly customized and heterogeneous ERP environments. SDT provides the opportunity to shed legacy burdens while preserving historical knowledge ‚Äì but only where it is truly needed.

 

Functional Realignment Within the Target System

One of SDT‚Äôs key strengths lies in the ability to implement functional innovations as part of the transformation, rather than delaying them until after go-live. From the outset, companies can tailor their new system to meet tomorrow‚Äôs business needs. Practical examples include:

  • Universal Journal: Consolidates all financial data into one harmonized structure. This allows consistent reporting, simplifies controlling, and significantly enhances external financial disclosures.
  • Business Partner Concept: Replaces separate customer and vendor master data with a unified business partner view, improving data governance, compliance, and end-to-end process integration.
  • Logistics Enhancements: Features like Advanced ATP (for more accurate delivery date commitments) or Embedded EWM (for modern warehouse management) can be selectively implemented during the transition.
  • Modern Reporting: Relevant data can be migrated in a structured way and integrated directly into advanced analytics tools, ensuring data quality, real-time access, and media-free reporting processes.

The crucial point: these innovations don‚Äôt need to be rolled out across the entire system. They can be implemented selectively where they create tangible value ‚Äì in data-heavy areas, specific business units, or as part of pilot initiatives. Relevant historical data can also be transferred selectively to avoid disruptions in information flow. In this way, SDT becomes a catalyst for innovation, process modernization, and functional excellence in the new ERP environment.

 

Targeted and Flexible Data Migration

Beyond functional realignment, SDT offers a high level of flexibility on the data side. Companies maintain full control over which data to migrate, from which sources, and to what level of detail.

This means not everything is carried over, only what is relevant to the future system is migrated.

Examples include:

  • Selective migration of clients, company codes, or plants, for instance, in carve-outs or acquisitions.
  • Restructuring of organizational units, allowing alignment with future governance models or regional business needs.
  • Legacy data archiving: only the necessary data is transferred into the new system. This keeps the target system lean, reduces maintenance costs, and simplifies operations.

Even for transactional documents, historical records, or configuration settings, a selective approach is key: Which periods should be retained? Which document types are still relevant? Which customizations must be carried over and which should be redesigned or retired?

The result: a clean, harmonized target system, free of unnecessary legacy data but still compliant with all legal, regulatory, and business requirements, striking an ideal balance between efficiency, compliance, and transparency.

 

A Structured Approach with a Clear Target Picture

The success of a Selective Data Transition relies heavily on a clearly defined target picture and a robust methodology. SDT is not a plug-and-play solution, it is a strategically planned transformation process.

At the beginning of the selective migration planning stands one essential question: What should the future ERP system look like? To answer this question, further considerations are required, including:

  • Which processes should be standardized?
  • Which systems should be harmonized?
  • What data is truly relevant?
  • What functional improvements should be realized?

Based on this vision, a detailed analysis of the current landscape is conducted. This includes systems, processes, data quality, and custom developments. Often, the greatest challenge lies not in the technology itself, but in the lack of transparency.

Interactive workshops involving business and IT stakeholders ensure that the transformation is shaped collaboratively. This ensures that technical feasibility, business requirements, and strategic goals are fully aligned. Potential risks such as data inconsistencies, integration issues, or functional dependencies, can thus be identified early and addressed proactively.

 

SDT as a Key to Functional Excellence

Selective Data Transition is far more than just an alternative migration approach. It is a powerful strategic enabler for realizing functional benefits, modernizing processes, and taking an active role in shaping the transformation journey. Choosing SDT means more than adopting SAP S/4HANA. It means investing in a smarter, leaner, and future-ready version of your ERP system. For organizations that want to shape change rather than merely manage it, SDT is the ideal path forward into a digitally empowered future.

Discover more: Watch the full webinar recording now and learn how Selective Data Transition enables not just a technical migration ‚Äì but transformation with real business impact.

entry.title: SAPFPAYM not triggered automatically after F110 / Manage Automatic Payments
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I am facing an issue with Payment Medium Workbench (PMW) in S/4HANA.
When I run F110 (or Manage Automatic Payments), the payment run finishes successfully, payments are posted, and the payment advice notes are generated.

However, the payment medium file (DME) is not automatically created.
I always need to go to SE38 and run SAPFPAYM manually to generate the payment medium file.

In Manage Payment Media, the status of my items is usually "Downloaded", and I cannot change it to "To Be Generated".

Here are additional details:

  • Payment method is correctly assigned to DMEE format (e.g., FI_PAYMEDIUM_DMEE_CGI_05)

  • Program RFFOAVIS_FPAYM is assigned in the "Printout/Data Medium" tab of the payment method

  • In DME Administration (DMEEADMIN), I can see my file with "Data transmitted to external" checked

  • No DME file is found in AL11 unless I manually run SAPFPAYM

My question:

  • How can I configure F110 so that SAPFPAYM is automatically triggered during the payment run, without having to execute it manually?

  • Do I need to adjust the Payment Medium Workbench (PMW) selection variant, or maintain a missing link in the payment method customizing?

  • Could the status "Downloaded" in Manage Payment Media block the automatic generation?

Any advice or guidance on customizing steps to make SAPFPAYM run automatically after F110 would be greatly appreciated!

entry.title: Change Record work Items are sent to Business workplace and My Inbox
entry.content:
Currently the work items are sent to both My Inbox and Business workplace. Sometimes users click on the item in Business workplace and the workitem disappears with status completed without a decision which causes issues. 

Is there a solution to restrict the Change record work items to be sent to Business workplace ?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

entry.title: Database instance on High-availability System using SWPM
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am planning to set up an S/4HANA 2023 production system in a clustered environment.

The landscape consists of 6 servers ‚Äî 4 AIX servers (Node1, Node2,Node3,Node4) designated for the SAP installation and 2 SUSE Linux servers (Node5 and Node6) for the HANA database.

I have a query regarding the S/4HANA installation using SWPM.

I have completed HANA (Node5 & Node 6) and the ASCS installation on Node1 and the ERS on Node2.

Next, I plan to install the PAS on Node3, followed by the AAS on Node4.

My question is:

1. Is it Mandatory to install the Database Instance (High-Availability System) on Node3 before proceeding with the PAS installation, or can I skip this step and go ahead with the PAS setup directly?

2. What exactly happens or what activities are performed if the Database Instance is installed on Node3 prior to the PAS installation?
If this is required, please confirm whether the Database Instance must be installed specifically on Node3.

3. What are the implications or consequences of skipping the Database Instance installation on Node3 and proceeding directly with the PAS installation?

Regards
Appuru

During the proposal DR documents are getting picked but not RV, Is there a separate customization or any settings to allow the RV invoices.

entry.title: Setup a new ledger in the year of brown field conversion
entry.content:
Hi all,

we have the following problem: year is the calendar year in September we will have a brown field conversion from ECC, old general ledger and only one valuation (HGB). Due to the major changes in tax law, the customer now wants a tax ledger this year.

The SAP help pages state the following:

It is not possible to implement an additional ledger in the same financial year as the migration to SAP S/4HANA Finance.

Do someone know a ‚Äúworkaround‚Äù?

Greetings
Hans

entry.title: Error deleting BP ID via FM BAPI_IDENTIFICATION_REMOVE, when ID number is case-sensitive
entry.content:
Following the Conversion of our ECC system to S/4 Hana we can no longer use FM BAPI_IDENTIFICATION_REMOVE to delete BP Identification number that were initial save as case-sensitive. Message E330(R11) is return.

The reason is because the upgrade introduce the OSS Note 2745718, which assumes that all data has been save in upper case, which isn't correct, when BP Identification data was create in ECC via Master Data Template (MDG). 

How can we handle these cases? 

Is there a solution that allows to delete them independently on how they have been created?

Is there a solution to convert all case-sensitive to Upper case so we can keep using this BAPI?

Thank you in advance

entry.title: Unable to Register Program IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER
entry.content:
Hello SAP Technology Experts, 

I am currently implementing the integration between SAP S/4HANA and SAP Datasphere (Replication Flows) scenario.

However, during one of the steps, I am facing an issue regarding creating an RFC connection in the S/4HANA On-Premise system.

Note: I do not have OS Access, hence tried to execute the below command first from the program (RSBDCOS0). 
rfcexec -a IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER -g <Hostname> -x SAPGW<Instance no.> -s <SID> &
The initial path from where I executed the program was /usr/sap/SID/D<xx>/work.

It did not worked, then I coordinated with our partner team to add an entry with the Program name IM_HANA_ABAP_ADAPTER and the value of Host = *  Access = * Cancel = *
However still I am getting the error that Program IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER not registered error while testing the RFC Connection

Note: We have the DP Agent connectivity working with Datasphere and Cloud Connector Configuration Steps is also done successfully. Once we sort this connection issue then we can go ahead with the S/4HANA Connection setup

Anyone faced the similar issue ?
Looking for your suggestions and solutions.

Thanks and Regards
Anurag

entry.title: Everything You Need to Know About the SAP Young Professionals Program
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre an ambitious graduate looking to launch your tech consulting career, the SAP Young Professionals program might be the opportunity you‚Äôve been waiting for! This free, immersive training experience opens doors to become an SAP Associate Consultant and kick-start your career among SAP's. 

What is the SAP Young Professionals program?

It is a free, 2-3 month intensive training initiative from the SAP Digital Skills Center that aims to equip recent university graduates (with less than 3 years of graduation) with SAP knowledge, soft skills, and certifications that prepare them for SAP consulting-related position within the EMEA region. 

Graduates are trained in SAP technologies such as: SAP S/4HANA, SAP Analytics Cloud, Artificial Intelligence, SAP Business Technology Platform, within others ((Modules may vary by cohort or region).

Who is eligible for the program?

Applicants typically need to meet the following criteria.

  • Hold a university degree (Bachelor‚Äôs or higher). 
  • Be a recent graduate (within the past 3 years).
  • Be currently unemployed or underemployed
  • Show strong English proficiency.
  • Be citizens or legal residents of the country where the program is being offered.

Note: Specific requirements may vary depending on country and region.

What does the program include?

Over the course of 2‚Äì3 months, participants will:

  • Earn globally recognized certifications 
  • Gain access to SAP Learning Hub and be trained by SAP specialists 
  • Develop soft skills
  • Have the possibility of starting your career as Associate Consultant in SAP's ecosystem (partners + customers)

Is the program really free?

Yes. The SAP Digital Skills Center delivers this program at no cost to participants as part of SAP‚Äôs mission to close the digital skills gap and support sustainable employment. SAP invests in rising talent to help drive digital transformation across industries.

Is employment guaranteed after completing the program?

While job placement is not guaranteed, one of the key goals of YPP is to connect graduates with SAP partners and customers who are actively hiring. Many graduates secure employment within the SAP ecosystem shortly after completing the program. However, success depends on the graduate's performance, certification results, and engagement throughout the course.

How to apply?

Applications are submitted via üëâ SAP Digital Skills Center portal.

Keep an eye on the website or SAP‚Äôs social media channels for announcements about new program cohorts in your region.

entry.title: Need a Function Module for mass activation/inactivation of Measuring Point in SAP
entry.content:
Measuring Point can be marked active/inactive individually using tcode IK02> Measuring Point> Functions> Activate/Inactivate.
But for doing it for multiple measuring points at once in bulk- a function module is needed.
Need help in that regard.

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

entry.title: Growth Rebate in Condition Contract
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

We wants to reward our customers that grow their purchase value by more than 15% YoY. Rebates are only applicable if current-year sales exceed base year by a defined percentage.

 For e.g -   Base year: 2024 - Target year: 2025 - Incentive: 5% rebate on incremental sales exceeding 15% growth

Does this scenario us possible in standard CCM S/4 HANA 2023 ? if yes How? 

Thank You
